title: Flow Authoring
content:
Flow design

Reusing existing content

Because there are many flows and operations already created, check first if a flow or operation already exists on the ITOM Marketplace.

Create modular flows

It is good practice to design modular flows rather than a single flow that performs all tasks, and it would be even better to have many subflows with very specific roles. Each flow should have a single, well-focused purpose, executing one single aspect of the desired functionality. Also, the name of flow must be self-explanatory.

Modular flows are:

  • Easier to create. Separate more responsibilities into separate flows? Because each responsibility is an axis to change. When the requirements change, that change alters the responsibility of the flows. If a flow has more than one responsibility, then the responsibilities become coupled. This kind of coupling leads to fragile designs that break in unexpected ways when changed.
  • Easier to test. Breaking a large flow into smaller independent flows means that parts of a complex flow can be tested independently and likely with fewer tests.
  • Easier to maintain and enhance. Modular flows have greater cohesion. Smaller flows adapt more readily to new requirements and are more easily stabilized.
  • Easier to reuse. This “economy” eliminates the duplication of knowledge or logic that has already been implemented.
  • Easier to understand. Imagine that you have been assigned to fix a bug in the flow shown in Figure A. Now take a look at the flow shown in Figure B. Which flow would you rather work on?

Use step references

A step reference is a flow or operation placed in a wrapper and used in other complex flows. Step referencing is a common practice when reusing flows and operations. Step references are advantageous because a wrapper flow can be tailored to specific process and user requirements, thereby reducing the overall amount of flow authoring work.

Keep Flows Small

A flow should fit on the canvas with the browser window maximized, with a 1:1 view magnification. It is recommended that you employ modular flows. In fact, when you have flows with more than 10 steps, you should consider splitting them into subflows. While large flows where 10 steps or more are allowed, it is a best practice to carefully examine such flows to identify where sequences of steps can be broken down into subflows.

Small flows are:

  • easy to test
  • easy to debug
  • easy to maintain
  • easy to understand for others

Start step

The start step should be located in the upper-left corner of the flow, with the following exceptions:

  • The Start step has many responses, each of which leads to another step.
  • Placing the Start step in the upper-left corner would cause excessive visual complexity, such as transition crossing.

Transitions

Keep Transition Neat and Tidy

As much as possible, transition lines should not cross over each other.

 

Keep Transition Lines Out of Step Names

Use a well-chosen, meaningful step names. For example, in the following pictures, the diagram on the left is quicker to code, but the example on the right is easier to read and debug.

                

Layout

When designing a flow layout, it is a best practice to consider well-known process automation layouts.

Swimlane (cross-functional) diagrams are process flowcharts that can be expanded to show times (such as when tasks are complete and how long they take) as well as information about who is responsible for what.

Swimlane diagrams enable you to identify time traps - which processes take the most time - as well as capacity constraints, and which resources are getting bogged down with work.

For more details regarding the customization of the transitions, see Creating navigation lines between steps.

“Z” Layout diagrams progress from left to right and from top to bottom, and are best-suited when transitions (success, failure) to return steps do not cross transitions between regular steps.

“2” Layout diagrams progress from left to right and from top to bottom, and are best-suited when there are “central” steps - such as notification or exception handler - in the flow, or to avoid crossing transitions.
